Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps Teams: Novel Lab on Chip QCM and ECIS Sensor with Multiple Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed technology with its various applications will have an important impact on biomedical community especially in the area of pharmaceutical drugs testing. The average cost for the development of a drug is approximately $1.2 billion dollars and requires 10-15 years of development. The proposed approach could help reduce this cost and time. The proposed approach could provide a cheap and fast assay to test drug candidates in pre-animal studies, which could reduce the current costs of over $500 Million required to bring a new drug to market.

This technology is a multiparametric sensor that couples quartz crystal microbalance (QCM) and electric cell-substrate impedance sensing (ECIS) techniques. The viability, adhesion, and visocoelastic properties of cell monolayers can be investigated using QCM resonators, based on variations of resonant frequency. ECIS monitors cell membrane impedance values, cell attachment, growth and viability. By combining two sensing methods, the technology expands the ways cell monolayers can be monitored and facilitates cross validation and decreases false detection. The team has also developed ways to culture cells on the sensor surface for extended studies, and has used the sensor to study how breast cancer cells attached to the surface in comparison to healthy bovine aortic endothelial cells (BAECs), and how breast cancer cells reacted to different molecules in real time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The technology proposed for commercialization is a multiparametric sensor that couples quartz crystal microbalance (QCM) and electric cell-substrate impedance sensing (ECIS) techniques. The viability, adhesion and viscoelastic properties of cell monolayers can be investigated using QCM resonatos based on variations of resonant frequency. ECIS monitors cell membrane impedance values, cell attachment, growth and viability. By combining two sensing methods the technology expands the way cell monolayers can be monitored and facilitates cross validation and decrease false detection. We also have developed ways to culture cells on the sensor surface for extended studies over the course of several days. This technology was intended to be used as personalized device for doctor decision about chemotherapeutical drugs. Cancer cells from the patient could be cultured on the device and exposed to different cancer drugs. The time required for the cancer cells to dye is recorded by this technology. The sensor could also generate useful information about nonliving systems where changes in elasticity, viscosity and electric impedance of thin layers might be critical for product functions.

We conducted over 98 interviews with biological companies in many importat cities. The majiority of the biologists with whom we were conducting interviews told us that such a device will required a long time to be tested with human cancer cells in order to be approved on the market.

We decided to find abother commercial direction for our technology. We spoke to different petroleum companies and found that the petroleum viscosity is an important factor in the petroleum industry. We conducted 50 additional interviews with experts from petroleum industry. The general output of these interviews was that in the petroleum industry there are several simple devices on the market for petroleum viscosity measurements. Our technology will need to compete with thesew devices. At this moment we study the viscosity devices on the market and we focus to imporve our technology and test the prototype with petroleum products in order to confirm that we can measure the viscosity with this device.

At the end of the ICORPS project we decided to  continue to conduct interviews in the petroleum industry and to commercialize our technology for viscosoty measurements.
